title: Linear Approximation Function
text: Use the following equation $$L(x)=f{\left(a\right)}+\operatorname{f'}\left(a\right) \left(x-a\right)$$ to make a linear approximation, where f(a) is the function and f'(a) is the derivative of the function.

title: Plugging Into the Formula
text: Since we are looking for the linear approximation at a $$=$$ $$0$$, we know that the formula is given by L(x) $$=$$ f(0) + f'(0)(x - 0).

title: Solving for f(a) and f'(a)
text: Now, we must determine the values of f(a) and f'(a) to find L(x).

title: Determining f(a)
text: Given that a $$=$$ $$0$$, what is f(a)?

title: Plugging Into $$f{\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}$$
text: f(x) $$=$$ $${sin}^2 x$$ such that f(0) $$=$$ $${sin}^{2\left(0\right)}$$. What is $${sin}^{2\left(0\right)}$$? Use the graph to guide your answer, where $$x$$ $$=$$ cos(x) and $$y$$ $$=$$ sin(x). Remember that $${sin}^2 x$$ $$=$$ $$sin\left(x\right) sin\left(x\right)$$.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Taking the Derivative of f(x) to Get f'(x)
text: The next step is finding f'(x) by taking the derivative of f(x) $$=$$ $${sin}^2 x$$. By using the chain rule $$F'(x)=f'(g(x))(g'(x))$$, we first take the derivative of the outer function such that $$\frac{d}{dx} u^2$$ $$=$$ 2u. Next, we take the derivative of the inner function where $$\frac{d}{dx} \operatorname{sinx}\left(x\right)$$ $$=$$ cos(x). Lastly, we combine the two steps through multiplication to get $$\frac{d}{dx} {sin}^2 x$$ $$=$$ f'(x) $$=$$ $$2u cos\left(x\right)$$ $$=$$ 2sin(x)cos(x).

title: Determining f'(a)
text: Given that f'(a) $$=$$ 2sin(x)cos(x), what is f'(0)?

title: Solving for f'(0)
text: f'(0) $$=$$ $$2sin\left(0\right) cos\left(0\right)$$ $$=$$ $$2\times0\times1$$. What is the answer?

title: Putting It Together
text: Now that we have found the values of f(0) and f'(0), plug them into $$L(x)=f{\left(a\right)}+\operatorname{f'}\left(a\right) \left(x-a\right)$$.
